data.title: John Gotti: A history of the Gambino godfather's ties to Staten Island
data.meta_description: The legend of John Gotti has been well-documented over the years by the Advance, including his ties to the borough.
data.text:
Travis M. Andrews/Washington Post/Charles Sykes/Invision/AP

STATEN ISLAND, N.Y. -- The box office was not kind to "Gotti," and neither were critics.

But despite only grossing $4.3 million at the box office since it opened last month, the true events surrounding the infamous American gangster will not soon be forgotten -- especially on Staten Island.

From Snoope's Bar in West Brighton to Paul's Sweet Shoppe in New Dorp, "The Dapper Don" made his mark in a borough notorious for its mob ties.

Tony Carannante

The early years

A young Gotti made headlines in the 1970s following the murder of James McBratney in West Brighton.

In the above photo, then-NYPD Detective Raymond Taylor leads Gotti into the 122nd Precinct stationhouse in New Dorp.

Irving Silverstein

Scene of the crime

When the nephew of then-godfather Carlo Gambino was kidnapped and murdered in 1973, it was determined McBratney of Port Richmond was involved.

On May 22 of that year, Gotti and two other men, posing as detectives, accosted McBratney inside Snoope's Bar and Grill in West Brighton, pictured above.

After a struggle, one of the men fatally shot McBratney. Gotti struck a plea bargain with the Staten Island district attorney's office which resulted in a two-year prison term.

Steve Zaffarano

Mob royalty

At the time of Gotti's release from prison, the Gambino family had a new leader with an iconic home at Staten Island's highest point.

Paul Castellano resided on Todt Hill in a sprawling mansion referred to by locals as the "White House."

This photo shows Castellano, center, and fellow mobster Tommy Bilotti of Eltingville, left, heading to Manhattan federal court two months before they were killed.

Mario Suriani

'Hit' heard 'round the world

In 1985, "Big Paul" Castellano was shot and killed along with Bilotti outside Sparks Steak House in Midtown Manhattan.

Pictured above is Castellano on a stretcher outside the restaurant, where three unidentified men opened fire.

Gotti claimed the top spot in the Gambino family following the gangland shooting.

Tony Dugal

'White House'

Castellano's Todt Hill mansion pictured above in March 1985.

A new sheriff in town

A bulletin board in a mob investigator's office showed photos of Gambino members, including John Gotti at the top.

Also pictured was Gotti's top adviser, Salvatore "Sammy the Bull" Gravano, who at one time had a home in Graniteville.

Google Maps

Body found in New Dorp

Following an attempt on Gotti's life in 1987, the body of a man described as a religious fanatic who dressed like a priest turned up in the basement of a candy store on Staten Island, according to Advance archives.

Authorities at the time said William Ciccone was tortured and killed inside Paul's Sweet Shoppe, located at 44 New Dorp Plaza.

The business was owned by Gambino wiseguy Joseph "The Cat" LaForte.

Pictured is a modern day look at the commercial block.

AP Photo/Mark Lennihan

Gotti on trial

After beating multiple federal cases, the "Teflon Don" was found guilty in 1992 for charges that included murder and racketeering.

He died in 2002 at the age of 61 inside a federal prison hospital in Springfield, Mo.

Gravano sings

To the surprise of prosecutors, Gotti's right-hand man Salvatore "Sammy the Bull" Gravano agreed to testify against his former boss in a Brooklyn courtroom.

Gravano's testimony and FBI wiretaps were instrumental in Gotti's conviction.

AP Photo/Maricopa County Sheriff's Office

'Sammy the Bull' arrested

After a short prison stint and witness protection, Gravano moved to Tempe, Ariz., where he lived under the assumed name Jimmy Moran, according to a New York Post report.

The former Gambino under boss then pleaded guilty in 2001 to running a nearly 50-person, $500,000-a-week ecstasy ring. He was sentenced to 20 years behind bars.

In 2017, he was released five years early; he will remain on federal parole for the rest of his life.

Irving Silverstein

'White House' makes headlines again

Police responded to a break-in at the notorious "White House" on Benedict Road in 2011, decades after Castellano owned the property.

The incident was tied to the notorious "ninja burglar," who was chased from the property by the gun-wielding homeowner.

AP/Louis Lanzano

Victoria Gotti weighs in on the film

In a recent interview on "Morano in the Morning," Victoria Gotti weighed in on the film that documented her life.

She said the film was the most accurate one that's been made about her late husband, and that she lent some of her husband's actual clothes to Travolta for the role.

She said her late husband was mistreated in prison as he was dying of cancer.

Here, Victoria Gotti is seen leaving Manhattan federal court in February 2006 during a retrial of her son, John Gotti Jr.
